        So sad. And you're right -- Even those who didn't know Sedgwick personally or work in her field were transformed by her work.

        The English profs of Roxie's World pay tribute to a kind soul and an intellectual force gone too soon: http://roxies-world.blogspot.c....

          • AcadeMama
            • 5 years ago • 0 0
            • −
            • +

            "This was at a time when queer courses were being taught at fewer than two dozen schools, and almost nobody held an appointment dedicated to the field. The problem of identity came up: were queer courses for queer students or all students?"

            Even after this time, when I was a beginning graduate student in 2001, this was one of my first questions in our Queer Theory course at BGSU. Reading Eve Sedgewick helped me to figure out that it's okay for me to "do" queer theory despite being straight. Or, more importantly, reading her work helped me identify the areas of myself and my work that were/are, in fact, queer as hell. In many ways, her work gave me permission to enter into the conversation of queer studies and ask what were very often naive questions.
